did.repository: University of Minnesota Libraries. University of Minnesota Archives [uarc]
did.abstract: This collection contains the papers of Stephen Peckham, professor of chemistry and physics at the University of Minnesota.

accessrestrict.head: Use of Materials
accessrestrict.p: Items in this collection do not circulate and may be used in-house only.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Researchers may quote from the collection under the fair use provision of the copyright law (Title 17, U.S. Code). Requests to publish should be arranged with the University of Minnesota Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred citation
prefercite.p: Stephen Farnum Peckham papers, University Archives, University of Minnesota, Twin Cities.

acqinfo.head: Source of acquisition
acqinfo.p: The source of acquisition for the Stephen F. Peckham collection is unknown.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This collection contains the following items: the autograph of John Johnson Enmegahbowh, an Indian Episcopal clergyman. A holograph manuscript report dated 1877 describing the examination of the Red River valley water supply by Dr. C. N. Hewitt, Professor N. H. Winchell and himself. A holograph manuscript describing the meteor which fell in Iowa, May 10, 1878. A holograph manuscript dated 1878 which in semi-diary form describes his activities of that year. A holograph manuscript describing a trip on the Upper Missouri River dated 1880 (He also discusses in considerable detail an Indian dance he saw). A report of the evidence given before the coroner's jury on the explosion at the Washburn "A" Mill in 1878, together with supporting reports and documents. Copies of eight of Professor Peckham's publications on various subjects. A holograph reminiscence dated 1877 entitled "School suffrage for women in Minnesota and how it worked".

bioghist.head: Biographical Sketch of Stephen Farnum Peckham (1836-1918)
bioghist.p: Stephen Peckham was born on March 26, 1836 in Providence, Rhode Island. He graduated from Brown University, and was a veteran of the Civil War. Known as one of the leading chemists in America, Peckham was said to have located the first oil well in California. He was appointed to the chair of chemistry at Washington College in Pennsylvania in 1869. A year later he held the same chair at Maine State College. Later he was appointed to the chair of chemistry at the University of Minnesota. He was an authority on bitumen and the author of many scientific works.
Peckham passed away in 1918 in Brooklyn.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed under the following headings in the catalog of the University of Minnesota Libraries. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons or places should search the catalog using these headings.
